title: Facebook Antitrust Lawsuits: What They Mean for the Social-Media Giant
summary: U.S. antitrust authorities have been examining for more than a year whether Facebook used its market position to stifle competition. The Federal Trade Commission and a group of 48 attorneys general have filed antitrust lawsuits against Facebook Inc. The Wall Street Journal previously reported that a focus of antitrust probes were the company's past acquisitions of potential competitors, such as photo-sharing service Instagram. Here's a look at why Facebook's past deal activity is under scrutiny:

title: The Navy Stops Taking On Water
summary: Decades of cuts left the U.S. fleet at almost 1916 levels, but President Trump is changing all that.. The Trump administration this week is taking an important step to quicken the U.S. Navy's buildup after its disastrous decline under previous administrations. By the Obama administration's last year, after decades of cuts to shipbuilding and maintenance, the Navy had been stripped down to a fleet barely larger than it was 100 years ago. These 275 ships struggled to meet America's national-security needs, leaving crews stressed, basic maintenance deferred, and the country at risk. The shipbuilding industrial base shrank to a fraction of the manufacturing might that won the Cold War.

title: Schumer's Unemployment Flip-Flop
summary: His current Covid relief demands contradict his own bill from July.. Democrats are outraged this week that the White House rejected their demand for four more months of $300 in weekly enhanced jobless payments in Covid relief talks. "That is unacceptable," thundered Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer in a statement with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi. Would he say the same about legislation he introduced in July with Oregon Democrat Ron Wyden?

title: DoorDash's IPO Delivers as Shares Surge in Market Debut
summary: Stock jumps 86% on first day of trading, valuing the food deliverer at more than $70 billion, higher than many of its restaurant clients. DoorDash Inc. delivered for investors, surging 86% in its stock-market debut on Wednesday.

summary: The stock exchange now wants to be your diversity consultant.. There's a new Nasdaq high-growth industry: diversity consulting. summary: Sacramento can't pass out jobless checks without being scammed.. It's been a rough year for California government: catastrophic wildfires, power outages, and now massive unemployment benefit fraud. It appears the progressive paragon can't even make transfer payments without making a hash.

title: George W. Bush and the Covid Vaccine
summary: Credit 2020's speedy development in part to a series of laws he signed in 2002-06.. It's poetic that when the U.K. began its Covid vaccinations Tuesday, the second person to receive an injection was 81-year-old William Shakespeare from Warwickshire, his famous namesake's home county.

title: Trump Takes a Parting Swipe at the Executive Branch
summary: Stripping OMB staffers of civil-service protection will make it harder for the president to do his job.. We served as presidential appointees in the Office of Management and Budget under Republican and Democratic administrations, and we disagree on plenty. But we are in complete accord that OMB's career professionals are essential for effective government. They bring deep knowledge-built up over years, sometimes decades-of how government works, which approaches to policy have succeeded or failed, and why.

title: Tech Giants and Social Media Need Smart Regulation
summary: The digital economy should have a code of conduct that enhances competition and encourages innovation.. The antitrust cases against Google and now Facebook are a welcome reinvigoration of the government's power to stop monopolization. The cases, however, aren't enough. They will become drawn-out legal battles and will likely leave many anticompetitive practices unchanged. The U.S. should complement its litigation approach by following the lead of the British government, which recently announced the creation of a new regulatory body, the Digital Markets Unit, to enforce a code of conduct for the digital economy.

title: Airbnb, Once a Nuisance, Is Now an Attractive Investment
summary: The short-term rental platform made my neighborhood loud. I'm hoping it'll make my finances flush.. Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: The New Covid Resistance
summary: A population of deplorables is rising among people who aren't in MAGA hats.. Despite the Trump election challenges, despite the Georgia Senate runoff that has turned Loeffler, Warnock, Perdue and Ossoff into unlikely household names, the most intriguing consequence of the 2020 election is Nancy Pelosi's slim Democratic majority in the House. How did that happen?

title: 'Breaking Bread With the Dead' Review: Old Books in a New Class
summary: A professor argues that we should engage with the classics, not only in spite of, but even because of, our moral differences with them.. Alan Jacobs reports that, though he has been teaching old books to classrooms full of students for many years, lately when he walks into a classroom "fairly regularly the first thing I see is every head bowed before a glowing screen." Ever-present screen-based entertainment, a 24-hour news cycle and the constant connectivity of social media place us in a constant sensory flux. This is not a hospitable environment for the study of great books, but Mr. Jacobs argues that our current predicament provides even more reason for turning to them: Reading old books promises to lengthen our "now," situating and stabilizing us so that we become possessed of more tranquil minds and less dominated by impulse. Those who can tie themselves to the great minds of the past, Mr. Jacobs tells us, will achieve greater "temporal bandwidth."

title: Significant Obstacles Remain in Brexit Negotiations
summary: Decision on future of talks should be taken by Sunday, the official said. BRUSSELS-Talks between British Prime Minister Boris Johnson and the European Union's top official ended without breakthrough Wednesday night with both sides saying they would decide on the future of the talks by Sunday.

summary: U.S. colleges and universities are preparing for the spring semester with takeaways learned over the past several months. While some aim to bring more students back to campus, others are shifting to more online learning.

summary: Ottawa is poised to begin its immunization rollout as early as next week. Canada became the third country to authorize use of the Covid-19 vaccine produced by Pfizer Inc. and BioNTech SE, racing ahead of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration and Europe's main regulator to approve shots for its most vulnerable citizens.

summary: Gov. Andrew Cuomo urges hospitals to be 'flexible and nimble' to handle coming influx of patients. title: Try to Learn From the Past, Don't Rewrite It
summary: Don't abuse the inheritance of your freedom to bully others but instead use your freedom to reflect upon yourselves.. Regarding Alessandra Bocchi's "Ancient History Isn't Colonialism" (op-ed, Dec. 1): To the Brown University students who feel "harmed" by "white, Western civilization" generally, and by the statues of the two Roman emperors Augustus and Aurelius specifically, I'd like to make a suggestion: In the next term paper avoid any word that is derived from Latin, avoid any legal concept that originated in the Roman Republic and avoid spelling out in name any month of the year.

title: Innovation Unlikely From Biden Economists
summary: Only two of the five "economists" mentioned actually are economists.. A strikingly odd aspect of your editorial "Return of the Obama Economists" (Dec. 1) is that only two of the five "economists" mentioned actually are economists. Cecilia Rouse and Janet Yellen are true economists. Ms. Rouse is first-rate and a highly respected expert in labor economics and the economics of education. Ms. Yellen has had a long career as both an academic economist and maker of economic policy. Her extensive practical experience in making economic policy counts for a lot. Although her Keynesian understanding of macroeconomics is literally half a century out of date, she is a serious economist. Of the other members of the Biden team, at least two have literally no academic training in economics, business or finance. Jared Bernstein has degrees in music, philosophy and social work. Brian Deese has a political science degree and a law degree. Neera Tanden has a law degree. Why would anyone think such people will offer better economic analysis than, say, the supermarket butcher or a taxicab driver? Why would anyone call them economists? To do so is to insult the entire economics profession.

title: Celebrities Aren't the Only Buyers After Montecito Real Estate
summary: Resume Subscription. The coastal enclave of Montecito, Calif., which sits between the Pacific Ocean and the Santa Ynez Mountains in Santa Barbara County, has long been a desirable destination. Covering approximately 9 square miles, the town is known for its dramatic natural surroundings, pristine beaches, mild climate, historic estates and boldface neighbors like Oprah Winfrey, who owns multiple properties including a 20,424-square-foot, Neo-Georgian mansion on 40 acres purchased for roughly $50 million in 2001 and nicknamed "The Promised Land."

title: Roundtable's Policy Is Perfectly Reasonable
summary: As the former president of a small, highly successful technology company, I don't understand the criticism, even animosity, of some toward the Business Roundtable's policy recommendations.. Regarding "What Do We Expect From Our Corporations?" (Letters, Dec. 4): As the former president of a small, highly successful technology company, I don't understand the criticism, even animosity, of some toward the Business Roundtable's policy recommendations that companies 1) work in the interest of shareholders, 2) commit to delivering value to customers, 3) invest in employees, 4) deal fairly and ethically with suppliers, and 5) support local communities. These interests aren't mutually exclusive but in fact are mutually dependent. I understood that to support our shareholders' interests, we had to do the latter four things well to be successful, though I did have the view that providing well-paying jobs was our biggest contribution to the community. If we failed at the latter four, we were far less likely to be successful at our first priority, and the better we did those four, the more successful we were likely to be. I also understood that if we didn't make a reasonable profit for our shareholders and for investing in R&D, growth in our markets, etc., then we couldn't do the other four because we wouldn't exist.

title: Recounting Unconfirmed Ballots Doesn't Do Much
summary: Mr. Raffensperger is relying on completely irrelevant data to justify his claim that this "election was the most secure in history.". Regarding Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger's "Trump Runs the Stacey Abrams Playbook" (op-ed, Dec. 7): I would suggest that the cumulative and significant effect of the changes in voting rules by states, in some cases apparently in conflict with their own state constitutions, are the definition of "unchecked attacks on election integrity." With respect to Georgia, the process of hand-counting paper ballots and comparing their number to machine totals doesn't address the process questions around signature verification and residency status, which are the real issues involved in protecting the integrity of elections. My household received ballots for two people who are residents of another state.

title: Salazar Protected Jewish Refugees Like My Father
summary: Refugees like my father had much to be grateful to Salazar for.. Regarding Tunku Varadarajan's review of Tom Gallagher's "Salazar: The Dictator Who Refused to Die" (Bookshelf, Dec. 3) about the Portuguese dictator António Salazar: My father left Vienna, Austria, in June of 1938 on a train for Lisbon, Portugal, the only place he could go in Europe where he wouldn't be arrested for being a Jew.

When people are ordered to stay home, they still want to eat.

title: 2021 Genesis G80: The Finest Car $70,000 Can Buy
summary: Think that Hyundai's new luxury offshoot can't compete with the likes of heritage brands Mercedes, Audi and BMW? Think again, says Dan Neil.. MUCH OF THE reader mail this column receives, thank you, is phrased in the form of a question: Which car should I buy? This question gets harder every year. Lately, many of my correspondents want to know which three-ton super-SUV behemoth I would recommend? Um, none. It's my duty to observe that the supersizing of the U.S. private fleet represents a public health threat and a failure of regulatory and tax policy (I'm looking at you, Section 179 of the IRS Code). On average and at the extreme, SUVs and trucks have gotten too big, too wasteful and there are too many on the road. Don't buy one.

title: China Wants to Be the World's Banker
summary: The U.S. is in danger of losing its dominant leadership position in global financial services.. The U.S. remains the dominant force in the financial-services industry, leading in nearly every area of finance, from venture capital and private equity to banking and asset management. The liquidity and scale of U.S. capital markets support the primacy of the dollar, which allows Americans to pay less for foreign goods and helps finance U.S. government spending. America's financial leadership, however, is increasingly being challenged by fierce competition from abroad and by shortsighted and counterproductive policies at home. Maintaining U.S. financial pre-eminence should be a priority for the Biden administration.

Campbell Soup Co. said a surge in sales brought on by the coronavirus pandemic is receding, a sign that the acute changes in consumer behavior early in the pandemic may be moderating even as many people stay home while Covid-19 cases and hospitalizations reach all-time highs.

title: AirPods in the Shower: Accident or Innovation?
summary: Resume Subscription. Deven Machette's post-run routine began like any other. She ate some blueberry vegan pancakes, turned on the shower, waited until it became appropriately scorching, then jumped in. That's when she felt it: her AirPods still in her ears.

title: Lagarde Does Whatever She Can
summary: And who can fault her when no other EU leader has a better idea?. Mario Draghi's rubric during his presidency of the European Central Bank was "whatever it takes." His successor Christine Lagarde has been forced to adopt a different version: "whatever we can." That's the best read on the expansion of pandemic bond purchases likely to be announced Thursday.

title: Facebook Pledges $150 Million to Build Homes for Silicon Valley's Poorest
summary: Investment represents latest details from social-media company, which last year committed $1 billion to ease affordable-housing shortage in Bay Area. Facebook Inc. said $150 million of its previously announced planned investment of $1 billion in affordable housing will go toward homes for the lowest-income tier in the San Francisco Bay Area.

title: Clean Air: The Next Luxury Apartment Perk
summary: Resume Subscription. Author

title: James Harden's Stepback From the Houston Rockets
summary: The NBA star wants out with two years left on his contract. It's the latest saga pitting a disgruntled player against his own team.. Instead of reporting to Houston for training camp last week, James Harden went to Atlanta to celebrate the birthday of a rapper named Lil Baby, who reportedly received $100,000 in cash, a $200,000 watch and a bunch of honey bun pastries in a Prada bag as a gift from the NBA superstar.

title: DoorDash, GameStop, Pfizer: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: U.S. stock futures rose on hopes for new fiscal stimulus. Here's what we are watching as markets kick into gear Wednesday.

title: The Rise of the Giant, Empty International Flight
summary: Why airlines are actually scheduling more long-haul trips in December despite low passenger demand and Covid-driven entry restrictions. The lesson is clear: No matter the obstacles, there will always be people (and cargo) who will fly.

title: Chinese Vaccine Is 86% Effective, U.A.E. Trial Shows
summary: Health experts caution that more information on the trials is needed. DUBAI-A Chinese vaccine candidate showed to be 86% effective in protecting people against Covid-19 in late-stage trials, the United Arab Emirates said, a positive sign for the fight against the virus in the developing world.

title: A Holiday Gift Guide for the Person Who Has Everything
summary: Redeem a joyless year: Our guide to one-off, handmade or vintage presents with personality to enliven the holidays. Old-school monogramming and a swinging silhouette give this Bordeaux-colored Louis Vuitton Deauville Mini bag some vintage flair. Louis Vuitton Deauville Mini bag, $2,190, louisvuitton.com

title: Tracey Emin's New Margate Home and Studio, Revealed for the First Time
summary: Amid a pandemic, a slate of upcoming shows and cancer recovery, the British artist, who has lived in London for three decades, is making her way back to Margate. Inside her studio with original photography and rare access.. When Covid-19 brought the art world to a standstill in the spring, shutting down galleries and museums worldwide, Tracey Emin, one of Britain's most famous living artists, was already upending her life. As lockdowns spread across Europe, Emin was preparing to move from her home in East London, where she's lived for the past 22 years, into a big new place in the center of the city, a neoclassical spread with plenty of room to make art. And she was building a second home outside the city, a residential studio complex in a vast industrial space in her hometown, Margate, on Britain's southeast coast.

summary: Amid a pandemic, a slate of upcoming shows and cancer recovery, the British artist, who has lived in London for three decades, is making her way back to Margate.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Sinochem, ChemChina Consider Merger Plan
summary: Combination would create world's largest chemicals conglomerate. China is exploring ways to combine two of its biggest industrial-chemical companies without running afoul of pledges made to the U.S. in 2016 during the $43 billion takeover of seed company Syngenta AG.

title: Arrests of Immigrant Children at Border Climb
summary: Apprehensions of unaccompanied youngsters are up more than sixfold from April, signaling a possible crisis ahead. Immigrant children and families are again heading north to the U.S.-Mexico border in increasing numbers after a lull, signaling the possibility of a fresh humanitarian crisis and an early challenge for the incoming Biden administration.

title: Commodities-Trading Giant Trafigura Wins Big From Oil-Market Mayhem
summary: When oil prices went negative during coronavirus lockdowns, the trading giant had its busiest month ever. Trafigura Group Pte. Ltd., one of the world's largest commodities traders, posted a record profit Wednesday, making it a big winner from turmoil in crude-oil markets during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Kim Jong Un's Sister Blasts Top South Korean Diplomat Over Pandemic Remark
summary: Kim Yo Jong threatened Seoul's foreign minister after she questioned the North's account of Covid-19 cases. SEOUL-North Korea, quiet on foreign relations for months, vilified a top Seoul official over her recent remarks about Pyongyang's pandemic response and deployed an increasingly familiar mouthpiece, Kim Yo Jong, sister of the regime's leader.

title: China Hails Victory in Crackdown on Peer-to-Peer Lending
summary: Central-bank official says, 'by mid-November the actual operating P2P lenders had all been zeroed out'. China has declared victory in its campaign against online peer-to-peer lenders, a risky financing sector that has been zeroed out, a top banking regulator said this week.

title: Australian Inquiry Into Rio Tinto Caves Blast Urges Restitution, Transparency
summary: World's second-largest miner should negotiate restitution with aboriginal group after destroying ancient rock shelters, lawmakers say. SYDNEY- Rio Tinto PLC should compensate an Australian indigenous group over the destruction of two ancient rock shelters, an inquiry has found, while calling for an end to the secrecy over how miners secure land access.

title: Japan Plans Its Own Missiles Able to Hit North Korea
summary: Move would give Japan pre-emptive strike capability, but Tokyo avoids explicit threats against Pyongyang. TOKYO-Japan plans to develop its own missiles capable of reaching North Korea, part of a defense buildup that would give Tokyo the ability to strike if it anticipates an attack.

title: How Big Data Turned Into Big Business for Cyber and Privacy Lawyers
summary: Legal teams staff up amid new privacy regulations and surging cyberattacks. Marcy Wilder walked into her boss's corner office at law firm Hogan Lovells in 2010 with an idea that seems quaint in retrospect: Start a team dedicated to cybersecurity and privacy.

title: Pandemic Squeezes Pensions
summary: Pension managers face hard choice of taking on increased risk or seeking more money from employers and workers. America's pension managers are facing a tough choice nine months into the Covid-19 pandemic: take on more risk, or ask for more money from employers and workers.

title: What Fed Officials Said Before Their December Meeting
summary: Resume Subscription. Federal Reserve officials have been hesitant to give credence to market speculation that they will boost the stimulus they are giving to the economy via changes in their bond-buying program, as many of them have said renewed fiscal aid is what the economy really needs. Some Fed officials also have said they see no need now to change the central bank's support for the economy. With the interest-rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee preparing to meet Dec. 15-16, here is a sampling of what Fed officials have said since their last gathering in November.

title: Euro Rally Weighs on Inflation, Sapping Appetite for Stocks
summary: Currency is near its highest level against the dollar in more than two years; investors worry there is little that the ECB can do to rein it in. The dollar's weakness is complicating matters for both policy makers and investors in Europe.

title: Luxury Brands Follow Chinese Shoppers Back Home
summary: For the first time, designer brands opened more shops in markets like China and Japan than in Europe. Even after the pandemic has passed in Europe and the U.S., luxury brands expect to do a lot more business in Asia. Their next job is to reduce the burden of emptier shops in cities like Paris and Milan.

title: Aging China Must Work Longer and Invest Smarter
summary: An aging population may finally force the government to face long-needed reform challenges head on. China is getting older. That means the Chinese people will have to work longer. But deeper reforms will also be necessary to ensure income growth doesn't stagnate.

title: Fragile Covid-19 Vaccine Rolled Out in the U.K. Tests Global Supply Network
summary: Resume Subscription. The Covid-19 vaccines that British citizens began receiving on Tuesday had been sitting only days earlier in ultracold freezers across the English Channel.

title: Coronavirus Sneaked Past Safeguards to Halt Singapore 'Cruise to Nowhere'
summary: 83-year-old tests positive for Covid-19 on ship operated by Royal Caribbean after everyone had to test negative before boarding. SINGAPORE-Since coronavirus outbreaks on cruise ships shook the industry earlier this year, operators have tried to win back passenger confidence with options such as "cruises to nowhere" that circle the seas without making port calls. They have upgraded air filters, lowered capacity, required preboarding Covid-19 tests and enforced physical distancing.

title: Chinese Consumer Prices Show First Annual Decline Since 2009
summary: Consumer-price index in November was down 0.5% from a year earlier, led by volatile food prices. China's consumer prices dropped for the first time in over a decade in November, though economists say the decrease doesn't signal faltering demand in the world's second-largest economy.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: The Real Queen's Gambit: Catching Chess Cheaters
summary: The popularity of chess boomed because of the pandemic and a hit Netflix show. So did cheating-making chess narcs the game's most important figures.. In the year when everyone went online to play chess, and even went online to watch a TV show about chess, players developed a nasty new habit. They started cheating at chess online.

title: China Sticks With Tough Line on Hong Kong After U.S. Bolsters Sanctions
summary: Political observers say sanctions unlikely to force Beijing into easing crackdown on opponents. The Trump administration's sanctioning of more than a dozen senior Chinese leaders is the heaviest in a series of blows aimed at Beijing in response to its crackdown on Hong Kong. If earlier measures are a guide, the effect will be mostly symbolic.

title: White House Makes Offer to Democrats of $916 Billion Covid-19 Relief Bill
summary: Proposal is at odds with McConnell effort to exclude state aid sought by Democrats; administration also wants new round of direct payments to households. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration made a $916 billion coronavirus relief offer to Democrats, opening yet another front in the multi-track effort to reach an agreement in talks that rank-and-file lawmakers have been leading in the final weeks of the year.

title: Elon Musk Relocates to Texas
summary: Tesla chief is among highest-profile tech executives to leave Silicon Valley during pandemic, criticizing California's treatment of innovators. Tesla Inc. Chief Executive Elon Musk said he has moved to Texas, taking aim at Silicon Valley and becoming one of the highest-profile executives yet to leave California during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: DoorDash Prices IPO Above Expected Range
summary: Meal-delivery company's offering, capping run-up in valuation, is latest sign of new-issue strength. DoorDash Inc. priced shares in its initial public offering at about $102 apiece, according to people familiar with the matter, a sign of strength both for the meal-delivery company and the overall IPO market.

title: Biden Expected to Name Fudge to Lead HUD, Vilsack for Agriculture
summary: Ms. Fudge is a former chairwoman of the Congressional Black Caucus, and Mr. Vilsack led the Agriculture Department for nearly eight years. WASHINGTON-President-elect Joe Biden is expected to nominate Rep. Marcia Fudge of Ohio to lead the Department of Housing and Urban Development and former Iowa Gov. Tom Vilsack as Agriculture secretary, according to people familiar with the plans.

title: House Approves Final Passage of Annual Defense-Policy Bill, 335-78
summary: The passage far exceeds two-thirds majority needed to override a veto threatened by President Trump. WASHINGTON-The House approved final passage of a $740.5 billion annual defense-policy bill by a vote of 335-78, far exceeding the two-thirds majority that would be needed to override a veto threatened by President Trump.

title: Elon Musk Isn't Sweet on Candy Makers
summary: Tesla CEO says lack of hits shows hazards of consolidation; Mars offers to send him some new candies. Elon Musk has some sour thoughts about Big Candy.

title: Biden Introduces His Coronavirus Team
summary: President-elect also is scheduled to meet with civil- rights organizations that have pressed for diverse cabinet. President-elect Joe Biden formally introduced the public health team that will help him navigate the coronavirus pandemic and announced goals to curtail the virus during his first 100 days, as lawmakers raised questions about some of his intended nominees.

title: Twitter Has a Competitor
summary: Free speech platform Parler performs well enough to earn hostile media coverage.. Twitter has never been a money machine like Facebook or Google. But Twitter has completely dominated the market it created for 280-character political commentary. Until now. Having chosen to use its power to advance a partisan agenda, the social media company seems to have attracted a formidable competitor-so formidable that other media outlets backing Twitter's agenda are now taking aim at the upstart.

title: Army Disciplines 14 at Fort Hood After Investigation
summary: Report found that base officials didn't properly handle sexual assault and harrassment claims. Army officials announced the firing or suspension of 14 commanders or other senior soldiers on Tuesday over failures to protect troops dealing with sexual assault and harassment.
